children.subject: For Amazon you only get to know your team 60 or so days before start date, and while I've heard people get placed into AI-related projects, team/project matching is essentially random from an intern's perspective. (There may be internal discussion about who fits what team best and which team needs an intern with certain specific skill sets etc.) I personally wouldn't bank on landing an AI-related project. Maybe try doing research during semesters (Spring/next Fall), and intern during the summer?

Honestly it's almost definitely better doing research if you want a PhD. Most AI related things in industry for software engineers are implementation and unless you're in a position where you are contributing original ideas to a group that will publish papers, the internship will not be that beneficial for admissions.

Do the internship over the summer. There are more research opportunities during active school sessions than there are internships and doing a tech internship for a prestigious company will be a unique and rewarding experience, especially for someone who is already doing research and has it on their resume.
Thank you! :) I applied online without a referral. Just filled out the application and got a coding challenge about a week or two later. Then, interview!
Congratulations on the offer! As a side, may I ask how did you apply for Amazon? Is it by applying online, or referral, or career fair? Thanks!!

history.content: If you already have a solid research position lined up or if you know who you're gonna work with, do research. Otherwise, its a no-brainer.

children.subject:
1) lmagine equating prestige with learning. I worked at a relatively no-name startup last summer, and learnt more about how things worked in real life than I had in 2 years of studying + researching at Berkeley. 

2) You've been reading too much r/csmajors if you genuinely think Amazon has "poor" engineering talent and that its "prestige" has dropped. Is it the same as working at Citadel, Jane Street, or even Google with all their non-TC perks? No, but that doesn't imply it has "poor" talent. Is Amazon hiring more than it has in past years? Yes, but only because it's growing faster than literally any other company out there. 

3) I don't know whether you applied this year and/or interviewed with Amazon, but I know Amazon asked LC Mediums and Hards in not only the Online Assessment but also the Virtual Interview this year, so I don't think their hiring bar has really "tanked" in terms of difficulty of interview. Some people I know at this school got away with an Easy with a Medium follow-up, but on a larger scale LC Medium is about how hard you'd expect Amazon to be for interns.

I will however agree that pertinent research can pay more dividends than a Big N internship if OP's sole goal is academia/grad school. However, if OP has never had a Big N internship, Amazon would be a great addition to the resume, besides all the learning experience, while OP can research during the semester while taking courses.

I will have to disagree. I agree the company is growing very quickly, but with very fast growth comes less time for them to vet and get the best engineering talent. Most if not all Big N have better engineering talent than Amazon purely due to the fact that they spend more time recruiting and interviewing to make sure their talent is up to par and the best of the best. 

A company which sends out OA's in which many people cheat and then a singular 45 minute interview is NOT indicative of good engineering talent, im sorry

If OP hasn't had a big name internship and has had prior research experience, Amazon's a no-brainer imo, regardless of whether it took him 1 interview or 2 to get there. I can understand where you're coming from if you're comparing Amazon to a handful of companies and dismissing Amazon, but OP doesn't have a choice here between Amazon and those handful of companies here, he has a choice between research, something he has already done before and can continue doing during semesters, and interning at Amazon. I think Amazon is the play in this scenario, and we can disagree on this and that's fine. OP has also not specified where he'd be researching, and that would make a difference too. If it was the likes of BAIR and OP hasn't had experience with BAIR and the like before, then I could be easily convinced that research is the right move. If however OP hasn't been able to finalize research somewhere already, then it makes sense to accept the Amazon offer.

Do the research. Amazon's hiring bar has tanked lately and its honestly not as prestigious or as good a company to work for as it has been in the past in terms of quality of engineering talent. The research at UC Berkeley will serve far more dividends than working at a company with a poor engineering talent, you will probably learn less.
I disagree. If he already has research experience, it's good to have industry experience on your resume for grad school.

Since he is applying for PhD, I heard that all grad schools care about is quality of research/experience in research. Although there may be some internship programs that may lead to high quality original work, I heard most internships are insignificant projects. Especially in AI, he can’t get into top programs by merely doing what is necessary. He needs to publish in top conferences instead and get amazing rec letters, which only happen after researching for a while. Research can’t be seen as a “check this off of my resume list” activity like internships are.
I very much agree with Jonathan on this one.

I think it depends on want you want to do. If you want to be a SWE, then go to amazon. However, if you truly enjoy research/want to go into a research/consulting job later on, the do research (Amazon wont help you much  for grad school).

FWIW, depending on how closely you're involved with your current research group, spending a summer on research can give your PI a better idea of what you'll be like when you're working on research full-time. It's a different vibe compared to balancing it with your other responsibilities during the semester.

That being said, if you don't have industry experience yet, it can be valuable to see how much you enjoy it. My suggestion here largely depends on what you did last summer - if you stayed here for research last summer, odds are your letters of rec are already pretty good, and it's a good idea to get some industry exposure. If you've had an internship already, maybe worth getting more closely involved with your research group right before you apply to grad school.

That may not help much because I really just said "it depends", but I hope it does help :)

history.content:
I’m currently a junior and recently got an internship offer from Amazon as an SDE for this upcoming summer (yay!). However I’m planning on going to grad school after my senior year to pursue a PhD in deep learning/robotics, and I’m conflicted whether it’s better to go to Amazon (a pretty big, well-known company) or stay in Berkeley to do research.

I’ve been doing related research for quite some time now, and my course load for the next few semesters definitely reflect enough difficulty for grad applications. I’m not even sure whether SDE interns at amazon work on ML/AI related things. 


tldr:

1. Is it better to go to an Amazon SDE internship or research at UC Berkeley if I’m planning on doing a PhD

2. do amazon sde interns work on AI related things (like recommendation systems?)
